title: How far back can an HOA charge a new owner for dues owed by an old owner?
question: I purchased a property at Foreclosure auction in King County, WA. The old owner owes approx. 2 years in back dues which the HOA has filed a lien for. I contacted the HOA and they state they will not remove the lien until ALL back dues are paid. I need to know how many months they can legally collect for back dues on a property that has been through foreclosure. In many states they can only collect 6 months prior to the Foreclosure and any dues that accrue after the Foreclosure.
answers:
Some states make HOA liens for dues senior to all other liens. If that is the case, then the lien remains and the HOA can enforce it or seek payment. If the lien is junior, then the foreclosure by a senior lien holder voids the lower liens.

Talk to a Washington State real estate attorney immediately.

[This communication is intended as general information and not specific legal advice, and this communication does not create an attorney-client relationship.]

The land is in Washington; so is the HOA with the underlying CC & Rs. You should ask the title/escrow company what the law is. If the existing HOA lien is junior to the lien which is being foreclosed, you may want to get a local lawyer and argue that the HOA lien for old HOA debts are foreclosed and that you only owe for new dues as they acctue. Negotiation and facing the need to sue you might make the HOA amenableto reducing their claim. Good luck.

This is not legal advice, but a hypothetocal answer to a question posed by someone I don't know.
